alfredsnippet.snippet:
(cont'd)

"...  Quite rationally, where non-astronomers reached the limits of their knowledge of astronomical science, they followed their instincts and backed their most accomplished and highly regarded colleagues ..."

Eddington fell far short of the canonical rules of the scientific method. [...] In 1919, general relativity won the debate because it had the best public relations available. But this was not a new phenomenon. Indeed, there is a certain poetic justice in Sir Isaac Newton having been eclipsed in this way. After all, several recent biographies have shown that it was partly Newtonâ€™s power-play tactics as President of the Royal Society that managed to win unusually rapid assent for his own ideas two centuries earlier."
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - The Eclipse Expeditions Did Not Confirm Einstein's Theory - Part 13
